and nonprofit organizations, households primarily in the US.

And what you can see is that

And certainly, early on

because the price of equity,

the price of houses, everything

is a dramatic rise in wealth

in the US, and all around

are two things that

The price of houses

I would be talking about

So if I tell you that

Aggregate demand. Consumers will reach. They will tend to consume more. That will increase

So how does that happen? Well, that's the kind

So consumption in services

It works through

group of people, and so on.

And sometimes monetary

It was pretty dramatic
as an intervention. The COVID-19 recession
led probably to what-- no,

not probably. Surely to the largest combined

After these two

And this framework
that we're going to use to develop,
to study this is what Hicks and Hansen initially
called the IS-LM model.

I already hinted

I notice that you

Remember what we're

That is, we're

When we describe the

we said there is an alternative
way of describing it. Remember, I said as an

I equal to S. So the
IS part of the name comes from the part that has to

market. IS-- investment
equal to savings. And the LM part has
to do-- remember,

L was that component
of aggregate demand we had in the financial markets.

We look at equilibrium as
aggregate demand-- sorry, demand for money equal
to supply of money.

Supply of money was M. Demand
for money was y times L of I, and therefore the LM part.

That's the reason. That's a mnemonic for why this
model is called the IS-LM. IS stands for the part that
has to do with the equilibrium

in the goods market. LM has to do with
the part that has to do with the equilibrium
in financial markets. This model is a model that
combines those two equilibrium.

So we're going to be interested
in points in which both markets

are in equilibrium. That's the name
of the game here.

So that investment
